name: NEGOTIATIONS

values.comments:
MGMT 291 includes not only conflict resolution but also techniques, which help manage and even encourage the valuable aspects of conflict. The central issues of this course deal with understanding the behavior of individuals, groups, and organizations in conflict management situations. The purpose of this course is to understand the theory and processes of negotiations as it is practiced in a variety of settings. The course is designed to be relevant to the broad spectrum of problems that are faced by the manager and professional including management of multinationals, ethical issues, and alternative dispute resolutions. This course is cross-listed with LGST 206 & OPIM 291.
	Most students enjoyed this class with the exception of the grading system. Students felt there was a lack of feedback among the four short graded essays and therefore the grading was ambiguous and frustrating. There was no clear way to gauge one strategy’s success over another and ultimately made “effective analysis impossible.” Besides the grading controversy, the students felt the class taught them effective and important and practical life skills.
	Overall, students felt that Professor Mueller was not available to provide sufficient feedback on how they were doing in the course. While Professor Mueller was illustrated as a knowledgeable and interesting teacher, she was unable to mediate discussions and students were often cut-off mid sentence “if their arguments were not in line with what the instructor had in mind.” Many students hoped that Professor Mueller would teach and grade by “observing each of us negotiate.”
	This management class was for Wharton undergraduate students. The workload was described as “very light” but the grading system was equally ambiguous. The prerequisites of the course are: MGMT 100 and MGMT 101.
